column4: how do i add a sshfs mount to my fstab w/o puting credentials in the fstab?
you have to use keys to authenticate
MUST use keys? i can;t do something like a credentials file like cifs?
that's fine if i need to, but where does mount need the keys to be??  i know the server I'm mounting from needs the keys in the auth keys.
well the private key is a credential file...and yes, if you don't want to put passwords in fstab you'll have to use another method, i mentioned keys because it's the other popular mehod
you cahn specify the priv keyfile with -o IdentityFile="pathtokeyfile"
you can script  the connection / mount process

but to make sure it lands after the openvpn,  i need to write an init script (something i've still avoided over 10 years of linux use), and place it after the openvpn connection on which the ssh resides that i want to mount.
or else write it into my bashrc.
neither ogf those is nearly as elegant as i wish i could do.
/etc/rc.local is perfect for that. the "elegant" way would be to use /etc/network/interfaces and post-up, but "elegant" can be whatever you use, i use rc.local extensively for my own startup scripts
m_tadeu: mebbe yuo guys can guide me to a better solution. i need to access my phprojekt via sftp or sshfs, I'm trying to access it with PDT for eclipse.  i have a zend project.
not sure what you mean by "better", you want to make sure the mount is made after the vpn is up?

i guess my issue is,  i have gnome up,   and i can sftp into the project dir.. but eclipse can't find it.  so i thought if i mounted the sftp as sshfs, that would work,  and it seems far too complicated to be my first choice.

if so add "noauto" in the fstab line and make it mount after the vpn goes up, you can script the vpn connection or use /etc/network/interfaces, i must say i've never used the latter for vpns, but it'll probablly work
